items.title: Level Zero Health banks $6.9M to prove wearable medtech can take the strain out of hormone testing
items.summary:
- Level Zero Health raised $6.9 million in pre-seed funding to develop a continuous hormone monitoring device.
- The startup aims to eliminate invasive blood draws and support research for hormone-related treatments.
- The team plans to create a stepping stone single-use product for intermittent hormone testing next year.
- The target market for their technology includes both women’s and men’s health issues.
- Clinical trials for the first device are expected to conclude by next year, with hopes for FDA and CE marking approval.

items.title: X doubles its Premium+ plan prices after xAI releases Grok 3
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- X has raised its Premium+ subscription price to $50 per month after xAI released Grok 3.
- The previous price increase was in December, raising it from $16 to $22 per month.
- Users only have access to some features like 'deep search' and 'reasoning'; other Grok 3 features require a SuperGrok plan.
- Inconsistent pricing on X shows variations between $39.83/month and $50/month for the Premium+ plan.

items.title: Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, releases its latest flagship model, Grok 3
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s xAI launched Grok 3, its latest flagship AI model, with enhanced capabilities for iOS and web apps.
- Grok 3, developed using a significant data center with 200,000 GPUs, reportedly possesses 10x more computing power than its predecessor, Grok 2.
- The model includes variations like Grok 3 mini for quicker responses and Grok 3 Reasoning for thorough problem-solving, aiming to outperform OpenAI’s o3-mini model.
- Grok 3 introduces features like DeepSearch for AI-powered research and is set to have a “voice mode” and an enterprise API in the near future.
- A subscription called SuperGrok, priced at $30/month, will provide enhanced features including reasoning capabilities and unlimited image generation.

items.title: Thousands protest Elon Musk’s DOGE in NYC on Presidents’ Day
items.summary:
- Over 10,000 protesters gathered in NYC on Presidents’ Day against Elon Musk’s DOGE and the Trump administration.
- Protesters expressed concern over the access to sensitive data and dismantling of federal agencies.
- Actions of DOGE have led to nearly 10,000 federal worker firings and cuts to many government contracts.
- Attendees chanted against Musk, marking it as a significant protest in response to perceived government overreach.

items.title: Nextdoor’s Nirav Tolia thinks he can turn things around with AI; he has a lot riding on it
items.summary:
- Nextdoor has shifted focus from large-scale social media to enhancing local community engagement.
- Growth has stalled due to problems such as misinformation and user disengagement.
- Nirav Tolia, the founder, returned as CEO to improve the platform, holding significant shares worth around $1 billion.
- Recent user engagement is up 13%, with 45.9 million active users reported.
- Plans to integrate AI tools aim to enhance user experience and manage discourse quality.
- Challenges remain in addressing local political discussions and content moderation without suppressing free speech.
- The possibility of taking Nextdoor private has been considered in discussions about its future strategy.

items.title: Are your noise-canceling headphones messing with your head?
items.summary:
- Noise-canceling headphones may have side effects beyond hearing damage.
- A BBC report raises concerns about their impact on the brain's sound processing abilities.
- A case study mentions a woman diagnosed with audio processing disorder (APD) after regular use of noise-canceling headphones.
- Five U.K. audiology departments noted an increase in young people with sound processing issues.
- Experts suggest noise-canceling technology might hinder the brain's natural sound filtering abilities, and more research is needed.

items.title: The New York Times has greenlit AI tools for product and edit staff
items.summary:
- The New York Times allows product and editorial teams to utilize AI tools, including a new internal AI summary tool called Echo.
- Staff is encouraged to use AI for editing, brainstorming questions, and research, but must not use it for drafting or significantly revising articles.
- The publication plans to implement AI for voiced articles and language translations, while it is involved in a lawsuit against OpenAI and Microsoft for copyright violations related to AI training.

items.title: The hottest AI models, what they do, and how to use them
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Overview of advanced AI models released since 2024, detailing their uses and benefits.
- Highlights models from major companies like OpenAI, Google, and Mistral, including their specific capabilities.
- Discussion on AI model performance and potential issues, such as hallucinations and censorship.

items.title: These are the hottest AI models, what they do, and how to use them
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Overview of the fast-paced development of AI models by companies like Google, OpenAI, and Anthropic.
- Compiled list includes advanced AI models released in 2024 and 2025, detailing their uses and best applications.
- Notable models include OpenAI's o3-mini, designed for STEM tasks, and Google Gemini 2.0 Pro, excelling in coding and long text processing.
- OpenAI's Deep Research offers in-depth research functionality, while Mistral Le Chat serves as a multimodal AI assistant.
- The article emphasizes the quantity of AI models, such as those hosted on HuggingFace, and ongoing updates to the list of new models.

items.title: Trump fires hundreds of air traffic support staff as SpaceX visits FAA command center
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- The Trump Administration has begun firing hundreds of FAA employees maintaining air traffic control infrastructure.
- Firings started late Friday night, coinciding with SpaceX's involvement in creating a new air traffic control system.
- The Professional Aviation Safety Specialists (PASS) union indicates probationary workers were affected, who are not air traffic controllers.
- Employees were informed of their termination via late-night emails from a non-government address.
- The fired workers included aircraft certification specialists, aviation tech system specialists, and others critical to aviation safety.
- Congress has pushed for FAA to address safety issues and modernize its systems, with recent attention on several aviation incidents.
- SpaceX team is visiting the FAA command center to improve the air traffic control system.

items.title: What the US’ first major AI copyright ruling might mean for IP law
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- A U.S. federal judge issued a summary judgment in a case against Ross Intelligence by Thomson Reuters regarding AI training material.
- The judge ruled Ross infringed on Reuters' intellectual property by using headnotes from Westlaw for its AI legal research tool.
- The judge deemed Ross' argument of transformative use unconvincing, as it did not add new meaning or purpose.
- The ruling may influence other pending AI copyright cases, although its narrow application is noted.
- The decision distinguishes between Ross' AI, which does not generate content, and generative AI, leading to further discussions on fair use in AI training data.

items.title: X is blocking links to Signal, a secure messaging platform used by federal workers
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s X (formerly Twitter) is blocking links to Signal.me, used for secure messaging.
- This blocking affects direct messages, public posts, and profile pages, first reported by Disruptionist.
- Nearly 10,000 federal workers have been fired in a move to cut federal spending, leading to increased use of Signal's secured messaging for whistleblowing. 
- Attempts to share Signal links resulted in error messages indicating the action could not be completed.
- Musk's actions have drawn scrutiny and accusations of censorship regarding differing opinions.

items.title: What to know about TikTok’s uncertain future in the US and the people who want to buy it
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- TikTok, owned by ByteDance, has faced scrutiny in the U.S. over user data security for four years.
- A recent outage left millions without access to the app but it was restored quickly.
- TikTok's U.S. business is estimated to be valued around $60 billion, attracting multiple potential buyers.
- TikTok has had a contentious legal history with the U.S. government, beginning with a ban attempt by Trump in August 2020.
- A recent Supreme Court ruling upheld a ban on TikTok, causing it to temporarily shut down before quickly returning online.
- Trump signed an executive order extending the TikTok ban deadline for 75 days to negotiate a sale or partnership.
- Various investor groups are rumored to be bidding for TikTok, including a consortium called The People’s Bid led by Frank McCourt.

items.title: Gamemaker Polymath aims to make learning math as enjoyable as Roblox
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Polymath combines gamified mechanics inspired by Roblox and Minecraft with adaptive math lessons to engage children in learning.
- Children explore a virtual island, customize avatars, build structures, and complete math-related questions to progress in the game.
- Recently secured $1 million in pre-seed funding, co-led by Blackbird Ventures and GD1, with Liam Don as an angel investor.
- Features personalized learning using an adaptive algorithm to effectively teach math.
- Offers both at-home and classroom versions, with teachers able to monitor students in real-time during the classroom version.
- Launched in January 2023, Polymath has users in multiple U.S. states and countries including Australia, New Zealand, and the UK.

items.title: Mistral releases regional model focused on Arabic language and culture
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Mistral, a Paris-based AI startup, launched Mistral Saba, a model tailored for Arabic-speaking countries.
- Mistral Saba features 24 billion parameters, focusing on improving Arabic interactions while also performing well with some Indian languages like Tamil and Malayalam.
- The model can be used for natural conversational support or content generation in Arabic and is available through Mistral’s API or for on-premise deployment.

items.title: Olyn secures Beatles biopic for its ‘Shopify for filmmakers’
items.author: Ana Maria Jipa, Jeremias Buireo, Kiran Thomas, Malcolm Wood
items.summary:
• Olyn is a new platform for film distribution, dubbed 'Shopify for filmmakers'.
• The platform allows filmmakers to keep up to 90% of their revenue and promotes a peer-to-peer distribution model.
• It claims to help independent films gain visibility against larger studios by leveraging social media influencers for marketing.
• Olyn provides filmmakers with tools like geo-targeting, analytics, and audience data, facilitating direct access to their viewers.
• The first major release on Olyn is the Brian Epstein biopic, 'Midas Man', which debuted on the platform.
• Filmmakers are responsible for their own marketing, challenging traditional streaming models that handle distribution.
• The platform is also addressing piracy by providing instant access to films globally.
• Olyn has raised $2.8 million in funding so far, indicating early-stage but significant ambition in the film industry.

items.title: South Korea blocks downloads of DeepSeek from local app stores
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- South Korea temporarily restricted downloads of DeepSeek's app pending assessment of user data handling.
- The Personal Information Protection Commission (PIPC) stated the app will be available once it complies with local privacy laws.
- Users are advised to avoid entering personal data until a final decision is made.
- DeepSeek's data transfer of South Korean user data to ByteDance raised concerns.
- South Korea's Ministry, police, and a state-run company had already blocked access on official devices due to security concerns.
- Other countries, such as Australia and Italy, have also imposed restrictions on DeepSeek due to privacy and security issues.

items.title: Can sim drivers make the shift to F1? Max Verstappen thinks so
items.summary:
- Max Verstappen proposes a pathway for elite sim racers to transition to Formula One, leveraging their skills developed in virtual racing.
- Sim racing has become a significant testing ground for driving talent, lacking the financial barriers common in traditional motorsport.
- Verstappen believes proper training can help sim racers adapt to real-world driving, despite the challenges such as experiencing G-forces.

items.title: These researchers used NPR Sunday Puzzle questions to benchmark AI ‘reasoning’ models
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Researchers from multiple institutions created an AI benchmark using riddles from NPR's Sunday Puzzle.
- The study revealed that AI reasoning models, such as OpenAI's o1, sometimes provide incorrect answers when they 'give up.'
- The current best-performing model on the benchmark scored 59%, with future plans to test additional reasoning models.

items.title: Researchers are training AI to interpret animal emotions
items.summary:
- Researchers are developing AI systems to interpret animals' emotions, including pain.
- The Intellipig system analyzes pigs' faces to notify farmers of distress signs.
- AI has shown an 88% success rate in identifying pain indicators in horses after surgery using deep learning.
- Human observations are crucial for training AI systems to understand animal behaviors.
- The research is being conducted by teams from the University of the West of England Bristol, Scotland’s Rural College, and the University of Haifa.
keywords: University of the West of England Bristol

items.title: Broadcom, TSMC reportedly exploring deals that would split up Intel
items.summary:
- Broadcom and TSMC are exploring potential deals to take over parts of Intel.
- Broadcom may acquire Intel’s chip-design and marketing business and seeks a partner for the manufacturing side.
- TSMC is looking to control some or all of Intel’s chip plants, possibly through an investor consortium.
- Discussions are preliminary, with no proposals submitted to Intel yet.
- TSMC's interest is reportedly encouraged by the Trump administration, though support for foreign control of Intel’s factories is unlikely.
- Intel's struggling business has made it a target for acquisition by rivals like Qualcomm.

items.title: YouTube TV reaches new deal to keep Paramount content
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- YouTube TV reached a deal with Paramount to keep its content available, avoiding a blackout.
- The agreement includes an expanded streaming relationship, allowing Paramount+ to be available to qualifying YouTube TV customers.
- Content includes channels like CBS, CBS Sports, and Nickelodeon, with negotiations extending to avoid passing along additional costs to subscribers.

items.title: OpenAI tries to ‘uncensor’ ChatGPT
items.summary:
- OpenAI is changing how it trains AI models to promote intellectual freedom in responses.
- ChatGPT will soon address more topics, aiming for neutrality on controversial issues.
- Recent updates include the principle of not lying and offering multiple perspectives.
- OpenAI's changes may align with recent political shifts and vocal criticisms from conservative figures.
- The company aims to enhance user experience by removing content warnings, making ChatGPT feel less censored.
- The updates signal a broader movement in Silicon Valley towards a new approach to AI and content moderation.

items.title: Open source LLMs hit Europe’s digital sovereignty roadmap
items.summary:
- A new program aims to develop truly open source LLMs for all EU languages.
- The collaboration, named OpenEuroLLM, involves around 20 organizations, co-led by Jan Hajič and Peter Sarlin.
- The project emphasizes digital sovereignty in Europe amidst significant investments in local AI infrastructure.
- A budget of €37.4 million is allocated, with €20 million from the EU's Digital Europe Programme.
- Partners include EuroHPC supercomputer centers, and the project anticipates initial model releases by mid-2026.
- There are concerns about the feasibility of the goals due to the size of the consortium.
- OpenEuroLLM aims to create foundation models that reflect linguistic and cultural diversity across the EU.
- The initiative faces challenges in meeting high-quality standards while maintaining openness in data sourcing.
- Comparison drawn with another project, EuroLLM, which focuses on similar goals for open source AI.

items.title: Death of OpenAI whistleblower deemed suicide in new autopsy report
items.summary:
- Suchir Balaji, a former OpenAI employee, was found dead in his San Francisco apartment on November 26, 2024.  
- The city’s medical examiner ruled his death a [suicide](https://www.mercurynews.com/2025/02/14/autopsy-openai-whistleblower-suchir-balaji-died-of-suicide/), countering his family's suspicions.  
- Balaji previously accused OpenAI of [illegally using copyrighted material](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/10/23/technology/openai-copyright-law.html) to train AI models and provided critical documents for a lawsuit against the company.  
- He celebrated his 26th birthday shortly before his death and had plans for a nonprofit in machine learning.  
- His passing sparked discussions on [AI ethics and whistleblower dangers](https://x.com/elonmusk/status/1879796369038409877) in Silicon Valley.

items.title: North Carolina Amazon workers vote against unionizing
items.summary:
- Workers at an Amazon warehouse in Garner, North Carolina voted against unionizing on February 15, 2025.
- Out of 3,276 ballots cast, 25.3% were in favor of unionizing and 74.7% against.
- The results are pending certification by the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB).
- The worker group CAUSE blamed the outcome on alleged illegal intimidation by Amazon.
- Amazon's spokesperson denied any wrongdoing and highlighted the workers' preference for a direct relationship with the company.

items.title: Apple Intelligence could arrive on Vision Pro in April
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Apple is planning to add Apple Intelligence to its Vision Pro headset as soon as April.
- The update will be part of the visionOS 2.4 software and may have a version available for developers soon.
- Initial offerings will not include an upgraded Siri, and existing upgrades to Siri may be delayed due to engineering issues.

items.title: xAI’s “Colossus” supercomputer raises health questions in Memphis
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s AI startup xAI plans to use 15 gas turbines to power its "Colossus" supercomputer in Memphis from June 2025 to June 2030.
- The turbines emit hazardous air pollutants (HAP) exceeding EPA's regulations, with each turbine producing 11.51 tons per year.
- The turbines have operated since summer 2024 without public notice, and permits for this operation are still pending approval from the health department.

items.title: Perplexity launches its own freemium ‘deep research’ product
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Perplexity has launched a new deep research tool, joining Google and OpenAI in offering advanced AI research capabilities.
- The tool aims to provide in-depth answers with citations for professional use, unlike consumer chatbots.
- Perplexity's Deep Research is available on the web, with plans to expand to Mac, iOS, and Android apps.
- Users can select 'Deep Research' from a menu, generating detailed reports that can be exported as PDFs.
- The tool scored 21.1% on an AI benchmarking test, outperforming competitors but not matching OpenAI's 26.6% score.
- Unlike OpenAI's $200/month service, Perplexity offers a freemium model with limited queries for non-subscribers and unlimited for subscribers.

items.title: OpenAI teases a ‘simplified’ GPT-5 model
items.author: Cody Corrall
items.summary:
- OpenAI canceled the release of its o3 model, opting for a simplified product instead.
- CEO Sam Altman announced GPT-5 will integrate o3 into ChatGPT and its API.
- GPT-4.5 is expected to be released before GPT-5, marking the end of non-chain-of-thought models.

items.title: Marc Andreessen dreams of making a16z a lasting company, beyond partnerships
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Marc Andreessen discusses the future of his firm, a16z, considering becoming a publicly traded company.
- He expresses no immediate desire to go public but aims to create a lasting investment company rather than a traditional partnership model.
- Andreessen critiques traditional VC partnerships for lacking underlying asset value and dependent on key individuals.
- He cites historical examples like Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan evolving from partnerships to large corporations.
- a16z already resembles an operating company, with significant staff dedicated to marketing and supporting portfolio companies.
- He notes a key challenge in partnerships is interpersonal relationships among partners.

items.title: What is an encryption backdoor?
items.summary:
- The U.K. government is pushing Apple to create a backdoor for accessing encrypted iCloud data.
- The Investigatory Powers Act (IPA) allows the U.K. to demand such access, raising concerns about the implications of weakened encryption.
- Security experts warn that backdoors could be exploited by malicious actors, leading to identity theft and data breaches.
- The concept of a 'NOBUS' backdoor suggests only authorized agents would have access, but this is heavily criticized as a flawed idea.
- Backdoors have historical precedence, with past efforts such as the NSA's Clipper Chip facing backlash and failure due to privacy concerns.

items.title: These Google Photos alternatives offer tons of storage options at a reasonable price
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Google Photos now offers only 15GB of free storage, down from unlimited free storage for images.
- Alternatives to Google Photos include:
  - **[Flickr](https://www.flickr.com/)**: 1,000 photos for free; paid plans start at $10.44/month for unlimited storage.
  - **[Dropbox](https://www.dropbox.com/)**: 5GB free; paid plans start at $9.99/month for 2TB.
  - **[Ente](https://ente.io/)**: 5GB free, focuses on privacy; paid plans start at $2.49/month for 50GB.
  - **[Cryptee](https://crypt.ee/)**: 100MB free; paid plans start at $3.30/month for 10GB, includes document editor features.
  - **[Amazon Photos](https://www.amazon.com/Amazon-Photos/b?ie=UTF8&node=13234696011)**: 5GB free with Prime membership; paid plans start at $1.99/month for 100GB.
  - **[500px](https://500px.com/)**: Allows 21 high-resolution photos per week for free; premium plans start under $50/year.
  - **[Photobucket](https://photobucket.com/)**: No free storage; $5/month for 1TB.

items.title: Uber sues DoorDash, alleging anti-competitive tactics
items.author: Kirsten Korosec, Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Uber has filed a lawsuit against DoorDash in California, claiming anti-competitive practices aimed at restaurant owners.
- DoorDash allegedly coerces restaurants into exclusive agreements for delivery services, threatening penalties or demotion in app visibility.
- Uber claims this situation has led to substantial financial losses and hampered the growth of its service Uber Direct.

items.title: Court filings show Meta paused efforts to license books for AI training
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- New court filings in the case of [Kadrey v. Meta Platforms](https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/67569326/kadrey-v-meta-platforms-inc/?order_by=desc) indicate Meta has paused discussions with book publishers for AI training data licensing.
- Meta's AI partnership lead, Sy Choudhury, reported slow engagement from publishers during outreach efforts, leading to the decision to pause licensing efforts in early April 2023 due to logistical setbacks.
- The plaintiffs, including authors Sarah Silverman and Ta-Nehisi Coates, allege Meta may have used pirated ebooks for AI model training, raising concerns over copyright infringement.

items.title: AI Alexa and AI Siri face bugs and delays
items.summary:
- Amazon and Apple are facing delays in releasing generative AI features for their digital assistants, Alexa and Siri, respectively.
- Amazon has postponed the release of its updated Alexa, initially scheduled for February 26, to March or later.
- Apple's AI enhancements for Siri are experiencing engineering problems, delaying planned features that may now launch in May or later.
- Both companies aim to compete against advanced AI voice assistants from OpenAI and Google but are struggling with their timelines.

items.title: Figure AI is in talks to raise $1.5B at 15x its last valuation
items.summary:
- Figure AI, a Silicon Valley robotics startup, is in talks to raise $1.5 billion at a $39.5 billion valuation.
- This new valuation is 15 times higher than its $2.6 billion valuation following a $675 million Series B last year.
- The funding round is expected to be led by Align Ventures and Parkway Venture Capital.
- Figure specializes in humanoid robots for commercial and residential applications, reflecting growing interest in robotics due to the AI boom.
- The founder, Brett Adcock, indicated the company has potential contracts for up to 100,000 humanoid robots and has already sold some to BMW.

items.title: SailPoint’s dull debut did little to loosen the stuck IPO window, expert says
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- SailPoint’s IPO on Thursday disappointed expectations for a resurgence in tech IPOs.  
- The stock closed below the $23 initial price on its first day but improved to over $24 on Friday.  
- The company raised over $1.3 billion, using it for operations and debt repayment of approximately $1.5 billion.

items.title: OpenAI says its board of directors ‘unanimously’ rejects Elon Musk’s bid
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI’s board unanimously rejected Elon Musk’s $97.4 billion bid to buy the nonprofit governing OpenAI.
- Board chair Bret Taylor described Musk’s offer as an attempt to disrupt competition.
- OpenAI emphasized its mission and the bid was considered not in the best interest of that mission.
- Musk’s bid would have meant a conversion to a for-profit model, which is currently contested in court.
- Musk, a co-founder of OpenAI, is involved in ongoing legal disputes regarding the company’s actions.

items.title: Bluesky gets growth and analytics tools with BlueSkyHunter launch
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- BlueSkyHunter launched as a subscription service providing analytics and management tools for Bluesky users.
- It features an online dashboard for scheduling posts, automating DMs, and tracking various metrics.
- Created by Borut Udovic, the service aims to support creators and businesses on Bluesky's growing network of over 31.5 million users.
- The service offers a free 40-day trial, with a discounted price of $15 per month for early subscribers (regular price $29).

items.title: Global electricity demand expected to grow 4% annually through 2027
items.summary:
- Global electricity demand is projected to increase by 4% annually through 2027, according to the International Energy Agency.
- Meeting this demand will require new generating capacity exceeding the total capacity of Japan each year.
- Emerging and developing economies are expected to account for 85% of the growth, with Chinese industries driving a 6% annual growth rate.
- U.S. growth will be significant but lower than China, equating to the current demand of California.
- Low-carbon sources like renewables and nuclear are expected to meet nearly all of the demand growth.

items.title: How this weekend’s ‘Tesla Takeover’ protests against Elon Musk came together on Bluesky
items.summary:
- A grassroots movement against Elon Musk's actions gains momentum, organizing protests at Tesla dealerships for February 15.
- Initiated by Joan Donovan and Alex Winter on Bluesky, the protests aim to draw attention to government data handling and Musk's perceived lack of transparency.
- 42 protest events have been set up across various U.S. states, with participation from citizens concerned about Musk's influence on technology and governance.

items.title: DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng is reportedly set to meet with China’s Xi Jinping
items.summary:
- Chinese AI startup DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng to meet with Xi Jinping and other top politicians.
- The summit may signal a renewed supportive stance toward private-sector firms in China.
- Expected to occur as early as next week; Jack Ma also likely to attend.
- DeepSeek, founded in 2023, gained attention for its strong AI model performance against competitors like OpenAI.

items.title: NATO backs its first cohort of European dual-use startups
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- NATO launches its first approved cohort of startups under the Defense Innovation Accelerator for the North Atlantic (DIANA) program.
- The initiative, in partnership with the U.K., aims to enhance investment in defense technology, with 10% of VC funding in Europe going to defense-related ventures.
- Five startups were selected from 2,400 applications for a six-month accelerator program: AI Verse, EIFys, Metahelios, RVmagnetics, and Winse Power.
- Startups will work on dual-use technologies that benefit both military and civilian applications, focusing on areas like AI, sensors, and imaging technologies.
- DASA (Defense and Security Accelerator) is leading the U.K. efforts in collaboration with IoT Tribe and Atmos VC among others.

items.title: Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, said to be in talks to raise $10B
items.summary:
- xAI is reportedly in talks to raise $10 billion, which would value the company at $75 billion.
- The fundraising effort involves existing investors including Sequoia Capital, Andreessen Horowitz, and Valor Equity Partners.
- If successful, the funding round would bring xAI's total raised capital to $22.4 billion.
- xAI is considering purchasing over $5 billion worth of servers from Dell to enhance its AI technology development, particularly for its Grok models.
- The next major version of Grok, Grok 3, is expected to be released in the coming weeks and is said to outperform other chatbots.

items.title: Meta’s next big bet may be humanoid robotics
items.summary:
- Meta is forming a new team within its Reality Labs division to develop humanoid robots for physical tasks.
- The new robotics group will be led by Marc Whitten, former CEO of Cruise, focusing on hardware and AI.
- Meta plans to create a hardware foundation for the robotics market, rather than building a Meta-branded robot initially, and is in talks with companies like Unitree Robotics and Figure AI for collaboration.

items.title: AI and security startups blossom on cloudy days
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- Startups related to security and sovereignty raised significant funding despite a clouded economic outlook.
- AI startups raised $110 billion in 2024, a 62% increase year-on-year, while overall startup funding declined by 12%.
- European defense and security tech startups raised $5.2 billion in 2024, comprising 10% of all VC funding in the region, at a record high.
- Mistral AI’s assistant Le Chat became the most downloaded iOS app in France during the Paris AI Summit.
- Data acquired SafeBase for $250 million; CyberArk bought Zilla Security for $165 million, with a potential additional $10 million based on milestones.

items.title: Meta confirms ‘Project Waterworth,’ a global subsea cable project spanning 50,000 kilometers
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Meta has announced Project Waterworth, a subsea cable project of 50,000 kilometers, making it the world's longest.
- The network will connect five continents with landing points in the U.S., Brazil, India, South Africa, among others.
- The project will utilize 24 fiber pair cables with innovative routing to enhance deep-water cable placement.
- Geopolitical factors influenced the project, with a U.S.-India joint statement mentioning cooperation in undersea technologies.
- The cable aims to support digital communication, video services, and online transactions, particularly focused on AI growth in India.
- This is Meta's first wholly-owned cable project, adding it to the ranks of other tech giants involved in subsea infrastructure.

items.title: Mastodon is working to add the controversial ‘quote posts’ feature
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Mastodon introduces the controversial quote posts feature similar to Twitter's.
- The feature has divided users due to its potential for online abuse and negativity.
- Some users support quote posts for easier referencing and response.
- Mastodon will allow users to control whether their posts can be quoted, and users will be notified if their posts are quoted.
- The feature aims to address user safety and privacy concerns amid implementation challenges with ActivityPub protocol.
- Development timelines remain unclear, with Mastodon stating it will take more time to develop the feature.

items.title: DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- DeepSeek has gained significant popularity as its chatbot app rose to the top of the App Store and Google Play charts.
- Backed by High-Flyer Capital Management, the company focuses on AI tools for trading.
- Key models include DeepSeek Coder, LLM, Chat, DeepSeek-V2, and DeepSeek-V3, noted for cost efficiency and performance.
- The reasoning model R1 claims to perform well against OpenAI's models but is subject to regulatory controls in China.
- Despite success, some companies and governments are blocking or banning DeepSeek due to security concerns.
